title:
Flexure based fibre positioners: design optimisation to follow arbitrary
  focal plane curvature
authors: Tom Louth, Stephen Watson, David Montgomery
abstract:
The use of flexures to achieve fibre positioner motion is being actively
investigated by several institutes, for example at the UK Astronomy Technology
Centre (UKATC) and Leibniz-Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam. One challenge
when designing with flexures is the large number of degrees of freedom
available which makes it difficult or impossible to optimise their motion by
hand. In this paper we demonstrate two approaches for optimising flexure
geometry to follow arbitrary focal surface curvature and to orient the optical
fibre with arbitrary tilt. These approaches are: analytical using MATLAB models
and FEA based using Ansys. The approaches are complementary allowing the
designer to efficiently explore the parameter space and then do precise
optimisation of the flexure geometry. We demonstrate the applicability both to
the UKATCs preferred design for WST, and to flexure-based fibre positioner
designs generally. We also present a sensitivity analysis relating small
changes in design parameters to changes in fibre tip motion. Finally we briefly
present the UKATCs preferred geometry for the WST fibre positioner.
